Posts.Title: Sheff is an Angel Sheff dawny

Posts.Content: Angela-R wrote: Hi all. I posted his on the healthy recipe threads, but as this is my " home" I thought I'd share with you ladies too. Second time on Chemo that wrecks my tastebuds, and I love to eat. I have had a little breakthrough with working out what will taste good and what will turn to #Â£>p in my mouth...fats and oils! I wonder if anyone else finds this. All fresh fruit and veggies taste fine, but nearly everything else doesn't. I have started making clear soups, eating food "stir fried" in water, baked non-oily fish in the oven, eaten toast with jam and no butter, and everything tastes better. Of course I still eat some of my favourites, chocolate etc. I just try to trick my brain that it tastes good. Would be interested in feed back. Cheers Angela Angela Dx 2/7/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 16/18 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Dx 4/1/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 21/21 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Dx 4/23/2012, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemo tastebuds breakthrough for me Angela-R Kellygrl77

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2013 04:32AM Angela-R wrote: Hi all. I am 49 and feel so lucky to read and be a small part of this group. Diagnosed stage 3 in 2009 on Black Saturday (the day we lost 171 people in the Victorian bushfires.) None of us will forget that day. Recurrence in opposite lymph nodes with no related primary in early 2011, then Stage 4 in early 2012 with soft tissue tumours in chest area and multiple nodes, but I have created a new stage for myself...Stage 3 1/2 ! Have had multiple operations but most tumours are not operable so am on Stage 4 chemo to stop the progress and hope to keep it away from the vital organs as long as possible. Son 19 just finished first year Uni, daughter 17 about to do final year of high school. They were 13 and 15 at original diagnosis, and i now hope to see them both into adulthood. Wonderful husband. Life's pretty good really. Cheers Angela

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2012 11:21PM Angela-R wrote: No expert opinion here, just a hug of support. The is so tough. Mine are now 17 and 19 and I know that they want to know whenever anything changes. Even when younger, I think their fear of the unknown was always worse than the practical information we gave them. But at the age of yours, I really don't know. Getting them some specialist support makes sense. And just love them. Only you can love them as their Mum. Maybe ask others to do the tough love stuff, and you just enjoy them. Idealistic? Probably, but they will get through this. They will be different to the way they would have been in the Brady Bunch, but knowing you love them, as they are, always, may be a strong influence in their adult lives. We can only do the best we can do, and it sounds like you are doing at least the very best you can. With love Angela

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 04:10AM Angela-R wrote: Wow, what a great idea. Sorry, I know nothing about the US system. Over here, we can go to university or college and defer payment. The government pays for you, and you only have to pay it back gradually through taxes when you earn over about $30,000. If you pass away, the debt goes with you so it doesn't come out of your estate. I don't believe you need to answer any medical questions to start out either. I seriously hope a similar opportunity exists for you. Studying would be such a fulfilling way to keep on living. Good luck, Angela

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2013 02:23AM Angela-R wrote: As a relative newbie, I have truly appreciated the posts from you ladies and others. You help more people than you can ever know. When I see that another treasured friend has become an angel, I watch with sadness as you all pour out your grief. I haven't known these ladies very well; Kita was the first, but I know this will start to happen to me, and I need to decide whether or not to put myself through that. At this time I think I probably will continue through it. My needs keep changing. Sometimes I am seeking support, answers, guidance. Other times I feel strong and want to help others feel better. When I am "well" I feel guilty about posting too much because so many others are struggling. I tend to just respond to others' posts. So I didn't have the pleasure of reading the posts from the women who left before I joined, and I imagine the Stage IV board changes in flavour as different people join. But I treasure the comments from those who have been here for a long time. Your wisdom is absolutely irreplaceable. Thanks Angela

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 04:20AM Angela-R wrote: Ann, I'm so sorry you had to get such a ratbag complain. I have read this site and parts of your blog for a year or so now, and only recently have I joined in. You are one of the primary names I always look for to read your posts. You are so honest, funny, warm, generous and so very normal, that I have gained great strength from you. It has made me very sad to read of your recent challenges, and I have to remind myself that we really are all just human, doing the very best we can. Any complaint is hard to hear, even from an uninformed person, but when you are down, as you probably are at the moment, you may just not have the strength to dust it off. Well, Ann, let us dust it off for you. We all know the truth. Together we are strong enough to repel such negativity. I hope you can continue to do the things that really matter to you, and I wish you all the positive energy I can.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 04:38PM Angela-R wrote: I too gained weight during initial treatment, mainly over eating and inactivity. A little help from steroids. The year after I got back on my bike and worked to get healthy, didn't lose weight but was toned and reasonably fit for a largish old bird. Then I fell off my bike, broke a shoulder, out of action for months. Stage 4 diagnosis happened while still disabled so the weight just went back on plus more. Treatment SEs took away walking and riding but I love swimming so off I went again. From January this year to May, I ate very healthy and calorie controlled food, swam a lot and lost 18kg (lb?) Got back into ALL my per-cancer clothes, felt fantastic. Then in May, another tumour, surgery, radiation, chemo SEs mean I cannot move much due to breathing difficulties. I am determined to keep as much of this weight off as possible, whilst still staying strong and fighting my main enemy and here's why... When cancer came back in May, I felt hopeless, lost and like I had no control over anything. The fact that I could wear anything in my wardrobe and look ok gave me great positive energy and a big smile. I don't want to lose that feeling. I am on steroids again and I am inactive, but I am trying to eat as much healthy food and avoid the junk as much as possible. Look, when we are battling this bugger, it really seems stupid to worry about our weight and how we look, and of course my number one priority is to be here for my family as long as possible, but I also want to live a happy life; not be depressed in my final years. For me to be able to dress reasonably and not feel unattractive makes me feel stronger and happier. I will do what I must to fight cancer and I will do what I can to stay healthy and within a weight range that suits me. Love to all Angela

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2012 05:19AM Angela-R wrote: My turn to chime in. Not to scare you. Ask about an MRI of the Brachial Plexus ( bundle of nerves under the collar bone that come out of the neck). Multiple scans showed nothing but this scan found a large soft tissue tumour pushing on the nerves affecting shoulder blades and arm. It was successfully removed by a neurosurgeon. All the best Angela

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2012 04:20PM Angela-R wrote: Sherry, I'm so sorry you have to deal with this. Only you can possibly know how you are travelling with treatment, and only you can decide what you will and won't subject your body to. Easier said than done. When people say "you can do it again", I interpret that to mean that I can deal with any treatment, put up with all the pain and accept the de-feminization of my once-lovely body, and keep smiling like the soldier I am. People want to believe it will have a happy ending. I understand that, and my guess is that this wish is at the root of many of the stupid things people say to Stage 4 girls (ok not all...some comments are just bizarre!) But that doesn't give them the right to dictate what you do to your body. Sometimes we all need to cut ourselves some slack, be kind to ourselves, make the choices we want to make for our selves, and occasionally tell well meaning people to butt out! Again...easier said than done. Cheers, Angela

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2013 07:53AM Angela-R wrote: Sitting up in hospital feeling no pain, with food and assistance at a buzz, truly a great way to recouperate. I feel very well, and the palliative care team are working in my home to set me up for a return later this week or Monday. We are all dealing with it ok. This is a particularly nasty version of our shared nemesis, because it is completely unpredictable. So I just take each day as it comes, and we are all laughing and enjoying ourselves in a way that we possibly never would without these events. Please Karen, you can feel the opposite of guilt about the photos. I mean it when I say that I love reading everyone's posts and pictures. Similar to Facebook I can see what people are doing in their lives without the burden of visitors. Port Douglas is my favourite destination. Having been there a few times it brings back lovely memories of those holidays. So cheers ladies. Much love Angela

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 04:40AM Angela-R wrote: Well I'm here. Original tumour Feb 2009 showed a small amount of Her2 so I did a year of Herceptin after full on chemo and rads. Subsequent tumours and nodes have all been TN. Was on Xeloda for a while but had progression, so am now on Abraxane which is hopefully keeping it at bay for a while. My sister is also TN and just finished her year of chemo and rads. We will investigate the genetic stuff soon. I love to hear about current research into TN. I know they are trying to make it a priority but we do hear so much about the hormonal stuff. Cheers Angela
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2013 03:17AM Angela-R wrote: Ok ladies, time for the news. After a very long story I don't want to go thru again, I am in hospital with intense nerve pain and loss of movement in one leg and partial in the other. I have a massive tumour wrapped around my lower spinal column. Not operable. Start radiation tomorrow with aim to shrink it. Hope to reduce pain but may not return mobility. I am now dealing with the palliative care arm of my health service. I think I will not post any more, but may change my mind. I will read occasionally because I've come to care about you all but I need to focus on me and my family. So I send my love. Cheers, Angela xxx

Posts.Title: Nails and Abraxane.. Travelingpants2 SAMayoFL

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2012 11:43PM Angela-R wrote: Hi Michelle. The first time around I cut my hair in a pixie cut, then when it started coming out in clumps I clippered it and got straight into hats and scarves. The act gave me a sense of control. This time I started with a pixie cut, and have just let it fall gradually. It started to thin after about 3 weeks. Then it started to some out in clumps if I pulled it and when I washed it, but there is still a fair amount hanging in there after 4 weeks. I brush it gently and avoid washing it. It's now too thin to go outside, but I have enough to poke out from under my hats and scarves. All the best Angela

Posts.Title: [TNBC's] Metastasis Molecular Switch Identified placid44 LRM216

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2013 06:32AM Angela-R wrote: I had Xeloda for about 9 months. Hands were fine. Feet were sore, but only badly after about the third course, and whenever I had my week off the symptoms went immediately. I had a month break after the 6th course each time to let myself get back to 'normal'. I used Moo Goo which you can get at health food stores and some chemists. It contains milk protein so, although my feet peeled, the skin was always elastic and never cracked. I applied it multiple times a day and wore socks. I vote Xeloda. If it gets too much you can always stop it. Or have breaks. But you have to decide for yourself. I know you haven't had a break from the major chemo like I did, but it honestly was nothing like the side effects from the intensive stuff you've just had. Never easy choices. Cheers, Angela
